text: Hello and welcome to this podcast from the BBC World Service.
Please let us know what you think and tell other people about us on social media.
Podcasts from the BBC World Service are supported by advertising.
How does AI even work?
Where does creativity come from?
What's the secret to living longer?
TED Radio Hour explores the biggest questions with some of the world's greatest thinkers.
They will surprise, challenge and even change you.
Listen to NPR's TED Radio Hour wherever you get your podcasts.
We would all like some quick and simple ways to improve our health, but we're inundated with often conflicting advice.
So if you were going to try just one thing to improve your mental and physical well-being, what should it be?
Perhaps the martial art of Tai Chi to improve your immune system.
Maybe a few nuts to slow aging.
Or how about cleaning your teeth to give your brain a boost?
I'm Dr Michael Moseley and this is Just One Thing, where each episode will explore one thing you can start doing today to improve your health or life in ways you might not expect.
I'm at my bathroom sink
and I've just finished off doing something that should not only reduce my risk of tooth decay, but may also protect my heart and my brain.
And as you probably guessed, I've just been brushing my teeth.
Now doing this twice a day after using an interdental brush or some floss to remove the bits of debris between my teeth should benefit my overall health in some surprising ways.
And to see just how good a job I've done, I'm going to chew on a plaque-disclosing tablet.
Now here it is and here you go.
This should cut up the sticky film of bacteria, otherwise known as plaque, which I've missed.
And let's see.
Oh god, that's not good.
There's lots of kind of blue in my mouth and a particularly big bit of blue between my teeth.
That must be an area where I missed when I was brushing.
But at least I am giving it a go.
Here in the UK, a quarter of all adults don't brush their teeth twice a day.
And when it comes to men, it is one in three who don't.
Good dental hygiene has some obvious advantages, such as preventing cavities.
But beyond teeth, studies have shown that brushing and using interdental brushes on those tricky to reach bits may reduce your risk of stroke, stave off dementia and benefit your overall health.
So better brushing, better health.
I'm speaking to Laurie from North Wales.
Let's see if improving her dental hygiene is just one thing she'd like to focus on.
Hello, Laurie.
Hi.
Do you have good teeth or is a like mine full of fillings?
Full of fillings.
They're not too bad, but yeah, there's definitely a few issues with them.
OK.
So tell me about your tooth brushing technique.
Try and hit all areas, I think.
You do it twice a day, do you?
Not every day.
Definitely once a day.
And do you ever floss or use interdental brushes to get the little bits out?
No.
What about late night snacks?
Yes, I definitely do like a late night snack.
So do you make sure to brush your teeth before you go to bed?
After you've had your late night snack?
Not every time.
No.
You are very honest.
I like that.
So I have a simple but important challenge for you this week.
I want you to brush your teeth twice a day for two minutes.
Do it once when you wake and once before bed after that snack.
And do make sure you use the interdental brush at least once a day, preferably in the evening.
It won't take much of your time.
Do you think you can manage that?
Definitely.
Yeah, I can definitely do that.
I've asked Lurie to focus on her pearly white smile this week because preventing the buildup of bacteria in your gums can have big long-term benefits.
Although some bacteria in your mouth are helpful, the ones that cause gum disease can affect your whole body, causing damage in organs far away from your mouth.
For example, keeping your gums in good shape can benefit your heart.

According to a huge study conducted on over 10,000 men and women from the Scottish Health Survey, people who brush their teeth twice a day have lower rates of heart disease than those who brush once a day or less.
Why?
Well, one suggestion is that when bacteria from your mouth leak into your blood, this activates an immune response.
In the short term, that can be helpful.
But if it continues, it can lead to chronic inflammation, which damages the heart.
These bacteria can also damage the inner lining of your blood vessels, increasing fatty buildup, which in turn can affect blood flow to your vital organs.
Good oral hygiene could also help your body in its battle against diseases like COVID.
An Egyptian study, which looked at over 300 patients who had recovered from COVID, found that people with healthy gums were less likely to be severely affected.
Another study found that COVID patients with gum disease were over three times as likely to be admitted to intensive care, and these patients were nine times as likely to die from the illness.
Another really good reason for keeping your teeth and gums in good shape is doing so may also protect your brain.
A recent study of stroke patients revealed that over 80% had blood clots that showed the presence of oral bacteria.
And another study showed that people who have severe periodontal disease, that's inflamed gums, are also at greater risk of Alzheimer's disease.
I'll be speaking to a scientist about this surprising mouth-brain connection in a moment.
But first, let's check in with Lori to see how she's getting on with the challenge.
So I'm about halfway through the week and my teeth look amazing, the best they've looked in a long time.
I'm enjoying doing it in the evenings.
It feels like self-care.
It's quite nice to take that time out and sit there and use the interdental brushes.
I've stuck to cleaning my teeth twice a day, every single day.
It's actually helped me with the snacking, because obviously once I've done my teeth, I then end up not snacking in the evening, so that's been great.
So yeah, really enjoying the task and really pleased with how it's going.
It's great to hear Lori is enjoying her clean teeth challenge and it's helped her cut out some late night snacks, which is a bonus.
We'll check in with her one final time at the end of the week.

But now to find out why looking after your teeth and your mouth is so important for your health and your brain, I'm talking to Dr Sim Singh Rao from the University of Central Lancashire's School of Dentistry.
Good day.
Good day.
What exactly is gum disease?
It is formed by bacteria in the mouth.
It's like the dental plaque or the bacteria wedge between the gum and the enamel and forms pockets.
Eventually it erodes the soft tissues and even the hard tissues and then the teeth fall out.
Now obviously gum disease is bad for your mouth, but how does it affect the rest of your body?
So there is this intermittent drip of bacteria from bleeding gums.
Once that goes into the bloodstream, it can go to different organs all over the body.
And we do know things like diabetes, arthritis, cardiovascular diseases, stroke, they're all related to periodontal disease or gum disease.
So they can also cross the blood-brain barrier and get into your brain.
And that is your area of research, is that right?
The mouth-brain connection.
Yes.

So initially we obtained a brain tissue from diagnosed Alzheimer's disease patients and we examined Alzheimer's disease brains and non-Alzheimer's disease brains in the laboratory and looking for signatures of DNA from these bacteria from the gum, as well as any proteins that might be associated with them.
And we found they were exclusively within the Alzheimer's disease brains and not in the non-Alzheimer's control brains.
So you're looking at this brain tissue, it was only in the Alzheimer's patients that you actually found the presence of these particular bacteria?
That's correct.
That must have been an exciting moment, also slightly disturbing.
The idea that you can go from the mouth to the brain to dementia is a very big step, isn't it?
Absolutely.
As soon as we published our first study in the Journal of Alzheimer's Disease, we were constantly being asked, well, can you show us that they actually get to the brain?
It's incredible.
So the next study we conducted was in collaboration with the University of Florida.
So what they did was they caused periodontal disease experimentally in mice and what we found was that those bacteria had entered the brains of those mice.
Clearly the message is that oral health is unbelievably important for your body and your and what are the best ways of looking after your teeth and your mouth generally?
What are your top tips?
Top tips are obviously clean your mouth twice a day at least for two minutes each time.
First thing in the morning, last thing at night.
And also use fluoride toothpaste and brush it
and then you can let some of the toothpaste linger on into your teeth and gums so that it has the added protection for a little bit longer to act on the teeth.
So I'm told spit but don't rinse.
What about the tongue?
Do you do anything with your tongue?
Well, our research has actually shown the tongue gets very dirty.
That was a surprise.
Definitely, I think it's important to clean the tongue.
What do you think about mouthwashes?
Good or bad?
Well, I think they have their place.
We should really go by when the dentist has recommended its use and for how long.
Alternatively, if you feel that you want to use a mouthwash then I would certainly make sure that you understand the instructions on them.
So brush for two minutes including your tongue and just spit.
Don't rinse your mouth afterwards.
Most of us would also benefit from flossing or using interdental brushes before we brush our teeth.
A study of dental students in Iran found that flossing before rather than after removed the most plaque.
Another tip from the British Dental Association is to brush before breakfast and to wait a full hour after your evening meal to brush again.
And that's because eating creates acid in the mouth, weakening your enamel.
Brushing too soon after a meal can actually damage your teeth.
So there we go.
Let's check in with Lurie one final time.
Let's find out if she has been able to stick to her new oral hygiene routine.
It's the end of the week and I've actually really enjoyed the task that I was given.
I've really surprised myself by how relaxing I found the interdental brushes.
Aesthetically it's been brilliant.
My teeth have never looked this good.
People have even commented on how white they are, which has never happened before.
But it's also really good to know that I am doing something that could prevent dementia, could reduce my chance of getting heart disease.
So it's definitely a win-win and definitely something that I will continue doing as we go forward.
I'm delighted to hear that Lurie will be sticking with her new routine.
I've also been paying particular attention to my dental hygiene this week.

I already regularly flossed and brushed my teeth before this challenge, but since I started using those plaque disclosing tablets, I've begun to focus on areas where I obviously hadn't been that thorough.
I do believe that doing this will not only help me keep my teeth for as long as possible, but also offer health benefits beyond my mouth.
Floss or use an interdental brush, then apply the electric toothbrush and your gums, your heart and your brain will thank you.
So that's it.
It's just one thing you can incorporate into your daily routine, which really could benefit your body and life.
If you want to hear more of the series, why not subscribe on BBC Sounds.
On the next episode of Just One Thing, lift some weights.
How building your muscles can boost your brain power, improve your immune system and may even reverse ageing in your cells.
Officials say a case of mass hysteria broke out at a girl's school.
What starts with the strange illness spreading through a school leads us to consider one of the most profound issues of our time.
Young people are so concerned about the state of the earth and then they are labelled as hysterical.
I'm Matthew Side and in the new season of my BBC Radio 4 podcast, Sideways, I'd like to tell you stories of seeing the world differently and explore the ideas that shape our lives.
From that mysterious school illness and what it tells us about our collective anxieties to a 100-year riddle which prompts thoughts of mortality.
Search for Sideways on BBC Sounds.
No matter if you have a tiny head or a big ass or something in between, you don't have to worry about ageing.
